document.text: Zack Elliott Cheatham, 82, of Evergreen hid Tuesday, July 4,19TB in Medferi Care Center inIA 6 hhucg HI Bora in Appomattox County, he was a son of the late James Hudson, and MoUy Evans Chetttham. R t v u a farmer and dealer in cattle and horses and member of the Virginia Horse Show Association. He is survived by his wife, Mayme Chocklett Cheatham a son, James Elliott Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. a daughter, Jeanne C. Stanley of Appomat tox two sisters, Annie C. Bingham of Lynchburg and Alice C. Babcock of Columbia. S.C. four grandchildren, Zack and Nan Cheatham of Clear water, Fla., and Bill and Jan Stanley of Appomattox, and a great-grandson, James Hudson Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. Besides the immediate fam ily, there were present a niece, Mrs. Anne Branmgan. and husband from California a nephew. Cecil Robbins, and wife from Wilmington, N. O. and a nephew, Huck Babcock, from Columbia, S. C. and many cousins. Funeral services were con ducted at 130 p.m. Friday from Robinson Funeral Home m Appomattox. Burial was m Evergreen Cemetery. Serving as pall bearers were Jack Baker, David Paulette, Kermit Paulette, Edward Har vey, Leslie Goodrich, Jesse Franklin, Herbert Diadmond, and Henry Simmons.

document.text: WOODLAND Mr. and Mrs. Ben Newman, accompanied by their mother, Mrs. Eldridge Cheatham and Mrs. Wesley Driscoll motored to Washington week before last and spent the week-end. Misses Geraldine and Helen Coleman are visiting relatives in Lynchburg this week. Messrs. Herman Marshall and Marshall Cheatham, of iynchburg, were week-end visitors of their parents here. Miss Dorothy Woodson, of Farmville S. T. C., and Miss Olivia Rush, of Lynchburg, were week-end guests at the home of Mr. Wert Woodson recently. Mr. Sammie Cheatham, of Detroit, is visiting his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Cheatham. Mr. and Mrs. Josh Harve and son, of Lynchburg, spent Sunday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. E- G. Cheatham. Mr. C. R. Woodson has re turned from a trip on the Staunton river. Mr. and Mrs. B. J. Mitchell, and family, of Lynchburg, were dinner guests of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Coleman Sunday. Miss Virginia Woodson spent the week-end at her home here. On last Friday night the many friends of Mrs. Susie B. Cheatham Newman gave her a miscellaneous shower at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. W. Cheatham. After the opening of the many pres ents received, nice refresh- were served and the young peo pie enjoyed a nice time. Mr. and Mrs. Ben Newman are now making their home in Lynchburg and we wish them a long, prosperous and happy life.

document.text: without aid from the Govern ment. R. A . Cheatham was married on October 24, 1866 to Harriet Nelson CaWthorn, daughter of the Rev. John H. Cawthorn, a Baptist minister. They were the parents of eleven children, the youngest of whom Russell Aubrey Cheatham, served with tMfe Army in Europe during World War I. R . A . Cheatham died Nov. 6,1922 and is buried In the Cheatham Fanhily Cemetery three miles south west .of Appomattox, Va. on State Route 719. - I have always heard that my Grandfather was left on. the battlefield for dead, but an Appomattox soldier passing by found him and took him to the medical tent. They cleansed his chest wound by passing a silk hankerchief through it. His paralyzed left arm was cured by massaging over a period of years. My grandmothers fami ly did not want her to marry him as they did not think a man with only one arm could support her, a problem soldiers of ail wars have had to face.

document.text: With the theme, Vocational Agri culture trains future farmers to be better farmers, and the F. F. A. makes Future Farmers into better citizens, members of the Robert E. Lee Chapter, Appomattox, will tell part of their story to the public to morrow over WLVA, Lynchburg Television Station. Ralph Harris, president of the local chapter, will introduce four other members on the program. These members will be Claude Allen Moore, va senior and vice-president Ralph .Reynolds a junior and chapter treasurer Bob by Barger, a sophomore and dub sentinel and a freshman, James Cheatham. Each member will tell some phase of their vocational agriculture or F. F. A. work, starting with James Cheatham who will -tell that The Future Farmers of America was largely patterned after the Fu ture Farmers of Virginia, which was organized first. Boibby Barger will tell a little about the F. F. A. con tests, and Ralph Reynolds will ex plain the meaning of the symbols seen on F. F. A jackets and pins worn by these farm boys. Claude Allen Moore will sum up the entire vocational agriculture program as it affects high school boys, with parti cular emphasis on the farm shop phase of the program. Items made in the shop will be displayed and ex plained. The Appomattox .boys will appear on the RFD 13 program, Lynchburg, at 12 noon, Friday, Feb. 25.

document.text: Winners in the weekly football contest that has been sponsored for the past several weeks by area businesses have been announced by the TIMES- VIRGINIAN for last weeks contest. First place winner, with 13 out of a possible 15 correct 1 predictions, is Shelia Torrence of Route 2. She will receive a check from the TIMES-VIR GINIAN in the amount of  10.00 as prize for first place. Seven persons predictea correctly 12 games of the 15 in the contest. Going to the tie breaker for a winner, M. W. Cheatham of Spout Spring gave Appomattox 22 points over Amherst, this being the closest score to the 20 point actual difference. He will receive a 1 check in the amount of 5.00 for  second place. As the Seminole District ! ended play for the season 1 Friday night, the Football  Contest has come to an end for  this year. There has been much interest, shown in the contest and hopefully we will continue with a similar contest next  season.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. document.text: William Baxter Cheatham, 34, of Rt. 1, Appomattox died , Saturday as the result of injuries sustained in an auto accident. He was the husband of Mrs. Margaret Cheatham. Born in Campbell County, he was a son of Mrs. Mary Cox  Cheatham and the late Russel Cheatham. In addition to his mother and widow, he is survived by six stepdaughters, Mrs. Jannis Burns and Mrs. Dreametta Austin of Appomattox, Mrs. Armetta Carter of Brookneal, Linda Younger of Concord, and Mrs. Carnella Eubank and Ruby Younger of Lynchburg a stepson, Norman Younger of Appomattox three sisters, Mrs. Etta Hamlett of Newport News, Mrs. Mary Elliott of Brookneal and Mrs. Evelyn Stone of Hurt two brothers, Richard Cheatham of Concord and Elliott Cheatham of  Brookneal, and 10 grandchild ren. Funeral services were con ducted at 1 p.m. Wednesday at St. Lukes Baptist Church by the Rev. R. Q. Lawing with burial in the church cemetery. Carl B. Hutcherson Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: Wilkes 25 cents to make it run. Wilkes repaired the clock, collected the 25 cents. He promptly went to Martins blacksmith shop and paid 15 cents for a pair of pliers, and then 10 cents for a punch. Mr. Henry Cheatham had a 98 cent watch a good one in those days. But the Watch was broken, and Wilkes got the job of repair ing it. He found that a spring was broken, but he had no replacement. Put Wilkes was inventive, and he fashioned a wooden spring out of white oak wood from a chair bot tom. It worked, and he proudly took the watch to Mr. Cheatham, and asked 30 cents for his work. Mr. Cheatham paid off with a small pig, which later turned out to be blind. Wilkes borrowed a saddlebag to carry the pig home, and by fall had the pig up to 200 pounds. Mr. Wilke3 has a splendid mem ory and recalls in detail many events of the 1890 period in and around Appomattox. He recounted to the Times-Virginian his first trip

Mary Lula Brown Lerner Mary Lula Brown Lerner, 79, of 1508 Florida Ave., Lynchburg, died at 410 p.m. Sunday, May 1,1963, at Lynchburg General Hospital. Her husband was the late William H. Lerner. Born in Appomattox County, she was a daughter of the late William W. Brown and Mittie Cheatham Brown. She was a former employee of Consolidated Textile Co. and a member of Bethesda Presbyterian Church. She is survived by five sons, William Lerner of-Edgewater, Md., James Lerner of Annapolis, Md., Clarence Lerner of Loxahatchee, Fla., Wallace Lerner of Daytona Beach, Fla., and Russell Lerner of Stevensville, Md. two daughters, Edith Brooks of Concord and Mary Mitchell of Lynchburg three brothers, David Brown of Newport News, Tom Brown of Brookneal and Russell Brown of Spout Spring three sisters, Etta Stanley, Betty Williams and Eleanor Wilkes, all of Lynchburg 25 grandchildren 29 great-grandchildren and one great- great-grandchild. document.text: Westvaco employees have erected a new display outside their Court Street Office. We are hoping that the display will encourage people to use and enjoy live trees this Christ mas, said Westvaco forester Roy Cheatham. He pointed out that young, healthy Christmas tree plantations add to the well being of the environment by tempering wind, screening dust, preventing soil erosion, and providing wildlife habitat. Next , spring Christmas tree growers will replace the trees cut with new seedlings. Some folks have turned to plastic or tensil Christmas trees to avoid the danger of a drying-out cut tree. Dry trees are a very real fire threat that should not be ignored, but the solution to this problem need not be an artificial tree. A live

document.text: Wesley Chapel. Some of ns are anticipating quite a pleasant time at the Association his week, since the rain has laid the dust so nicely. Mrs. Henrietta W. Cheatham is siting her daughter, Mrs. H. E. Clarke, in Lynchburg. The revival begins at Wesley on Sunday next. Rev. W. J. Williams, of Red House, will assist Mr. Bell. Mrs. H. Drinkard, of Bedford, is visiting her people in this vicinity. Melons and croquet seem to be the chief means of occupying our pleas- iit afternoons at preeeut. 1 believe that everybody has had i good time this summer, more or less, and it will go a little hard, no doubt, with some of us to give up our pleasant, free-and-easy life that ue have been leading, and to take up again our old routine life but we cannot have all  sunshine and roses.

document.text: Well, well, lets see vhat there is to chronicle tonight? Whither, vaulted columnar ver nacular?    First, J. H. Cheatham had a birthday yesterday. He was down on the streets before 7 oclock doffing his sombrero in token of 68 birthdays. Yas sah. And Len Smith and W. M. Hancock had birthdays togeth er Chooseday . . . 69 I do bow- lieve.    Then, theres that fishing party of Tuesday. Our Col. Joel, E. T. Mitc.hell, J. H. OBrien, aided and abetted to- wit, wherewithal and whereas by Watkins Abbitt, garnered their earthworms and, hied away to Horseleys Pond, wherever that is. The Col. mussed up his shirt front with a sun perch. Cope teste, Father Darkleaf, et cafeteria.    Nfurthermore, theres the case of the right Rev. Lee. Hes dean of the colored parsons in Roanoke. Happened to be here attending court last week and when a pair of matrimonial- bound colored folks applied for a license said Rev. Lee was called in to do the honors right in the clerks office. Vo-do-de- o-do.    Theres something, it might be chronicled, whimsical about a bathrobe. Father Darkleafs favorite is one used for eleven years. Had several given me since I got thatbut my bones and joints dont feel right in em.    And orchids to Mother Bright- leaf. Shes twenty-seven cents on the blue inc side of our bud get for June. And keeps her ledg r like a veteran, she does. And I like the fare better than Delmonicos.    Oh yes, I forgot, the colored couples names were Perry Nathenial Brown and Annie Lee Mins. Thats the sort of a reporter I am .   and the parsons initials are W. E., since Im being downright accurate.    And folks, Im warning you, Mather Brightleaf is hot after back subscribers. And when I told her about the way folks wouldnt Subscribe for them selves but borrowed. their neighbors paper, she turned up her nose, she did and said, The stingy things. One subscriber on one of the routes this week said he had to put up with four families borrowing his Times- - Virginian. Scallions and ashes.    George Peery no doubt real izes hes gonna be the next governor, but hes taking no chances. Has a plaque on hijP office wall containing four-leaf  clovers, horse-shoes and a rab bits foot.    Lots of suckers will bet on on the big prize fight tonight. The only thing I ever bet on was when I called Mother Brightleafs bet that my mother didnt serve oatmeal for break fast. Proved it too, by heck.

document.text: We w ere sad d led when word came Sunday that Mr. W. M. Blade had passed away. Our love and deepest sympathy are extended her loved ones. Our prayers and sympathy are with the family and loved ones of Mr. Zack Cheatham, who passed away last week. We were very sorry to learn of the illness of Mrs. Sandy Baldwin of North Dakota. Our sincere prayers are with her and each of the family. We were very sorry to hear of the death of Mrs. Alfred LeGrande. Deepest sympathy is extended her loved ones. Mr. James Maxwell returned home Friday from the hospital. We wish for him a very speedy recovery. The families of the late Mi. and M rs. W. L. Turnes celebrated their family reunion Sunday at the home of Mrs. J. L. Torrence. Mr. H. W. Jenkins and son, Mr. Robert Jenkins attended the funeral of Mrs. Ossie Key of Bedford Saturday. She was a very dear relative of the late Mrs. H. W. Jenkins. Mr. and Mrs. Bill Watson and family returned home Friday after spending their vacation at W illiamsburg and Virginia Beach.
